title: 111_hr1802
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission on the Accountability and Review of Federal Agencies Act" and establishes a Commission. The Commission on the Accountability and Review of Federal Agencies is established with 7 members appointed by the President, including representatives from the House of Representatives, Senate, and three other members. The Commission on the Accountability and Review of Federal Agencies is established with 7 members appointed by the President, including representatives from the House of Representatives, Senate, and three other members. The President may appoint up to 4 Members of Congress as nonvoting ex officio members. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, and meetings are called by the chairperson. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for decision-making. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission, defined as an "agency" under section 105 of title 5, United States Code, is tasked with evaluating all agencies and programs to recommend realignment or elimination based on criteria such as duplication of essential functions. The Commission will recommend realigning or eliminating agencies or programs that are wasteful, inefficient, outdated, irrelevant, or failed. This recommendation must be submitted within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The Commission will recommend realigning or eliminating agencies or programs that are wasteful, inefficient, outdated, irrelevant, or failed within 2 years of the Act's enactment. Following the enactment of this Act, the Commission shall submit a report to the President and Congress including a plan with supporting documentation for recommendations and proposed legislation for deficit reduction and relocation of federal employees affected by the plan implementation. The affected agency must make efforts to relocate the employee to another position within the agency or another Federal agency. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 4. The Commission, subcommittees, or members may hold hearings, take testimony, and subpoena witnesses and evidence for investigations under this Act. Subpoenas issued must be enforced. The Commission can issue subpoenas signed by the chairperson for testimony or evidence. Failure to comply may result in a court order for appearance or contempt charges. The Commission can also obtain information directly from Federal agencies. The Commission can request necessary information from Federal departments or agencies to carry out the Act. The Commission is authorized to use the United States mails like other Federal departments and agencies. SEC. 5. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Commission members are compensated differently based on their federal status. Non-federal members do not receive compensation, while federal officers or employees serve without additional pay. Travel expenses are allowed for Commission members at authorized rates. The chairperson has authority over the Commission staff. The chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The executive director can determine their own compensation, not exceeding the maximum rate for a GS-15 position. The executive director and personnel of the Commission are federal employees under title 5, United States Code. Members of the Commission are not included. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured. The chairperson of the Commission may procure temporary and intermittent services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting the report under section 3(d). Congressional consideration of reform proposals will follow. In this section, an implementation bill is defined as a bill introduced without modification containing proposed legislation from a report submitted to Congress. A calendar day is defined as a day when either House is not in session due to an adjournment of more than 3 days. On the first day both Houses are in session following the report submission, a single implementation bill must be introduced in the Senate by the majority leader. Implementation bills introduced in the Senate by the majority leader and designated Members, and in the House of Representatives by the Speaker and designated Members, shall be referred to appropriate committees for jurisdiction. Implementation bills introduced in the House of Representatives may be reported without amendment by the committee. If a committee fails to report the bill within 15 days, it will be discharged and placed on the calendar for floor consideration. The motion to proceed to the consideration of the implementation bill is highly privileged in the House of Representatives and privileged in the Senate. It is not debatable, subject to amendment, or a motion to postpone. If agreed to, the implementation bill becomes the unfinished business. The implementation bill is the unfinished business of the House until disposed of. It cannot be amended in the Senate or the House of Representatives. Debate is limited to 10 hours, with equal time for those in favor and those opposing. Further debate limitations and amendments are not allowed. A vote on final passage follows immediately. After the conclusion of debate on an implementation bill, a vote on final passage occurs. Appeals on procedural rulings by the Chair are decided without debate. If one House receives an implementation bill from the other House before passing its own, specific procedures apply. The implementation bill of the other House shall not be referred to a committee. The procedure for voting on the bill in the receiving House is the same as if no implementation bill had been received, but the final passage vote will be on the bill from the other House. This section is enacted by Congress as part of the rules of each House for the procedure to be followed. The rules for an implementation bill in one House supersede other rules only if inconsistent, and each House has the right to change its rules regarding procedures at any time. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2010 through 2013 is provided in this Act.
